Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back with modelled clypeus and head, prothorax and elytra indicated by single lines, and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; side view unknown; underside decorated with a vertically arranged motif with sun disc and falcon holding a flail above neb-basket sign; motif possibly stamped rather than incised; pierced lengthwise; glaze lost; yellowish white paste; eroded surface.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Musée du Louvre. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Falcon, sometimes wearing a crown or with a flail like here, is a recurring motif for various compositions found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). According to Gorton, this scarab belongs to a standard group of the “Scarab Factory”, widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, notably on Punic sites and in the Levant, her type XXXI (Gorton 1996, 112-114, type XXXI subtype 3-18, see especially 14 for this piece). It seems, however, better fitted with her type XXVIII, subtype A140-148 (Gorton 1996, 98-99). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it seems plausible that the inscription was meant as a trigram to write the name of Amun in a cryptic way (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 58)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 112, Type XXXI 14) (wrong category?)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.043) (phase 3)
